project.teaser: The introduction of connected, cooperative and automated mobility (CCAM) can make a significant improvement to logistic chains. The MODI project will identify and largely resolve barriers on confined areas and on public roads for SAE L4 CCAM vehicles on the corridor from...
project.objective:
The introduction of connected, cooperative and automated mobility (CCAM) can make a significant improvement to logistic chains. The MODI project will identify and largely resolve barriers on confined areas and on public roads for SAE L4 CCAM vehicles on the corridor from Rotterdam to Oslo, and demonstrate the solutions.
Coordination is a central element of development in this project: it enables early integration of CCAM in current logistic vehicle operations, adding more efficiency benefits for logistics companies and thus creating an attractive path to deployment. Coordination is also needed for smart traffic management in the public domain.
The project comprises five different use cases, each describing a part of the logistics chain. It identifies what is already possible on SAE L4, and what is not possible yet. For the public roads, the project will focus on understanding and overcoming the regulatory barriers and PDI shortcomings on the motorway corridor with road authorities and OEMs of the project involved. In cocreation with all stakeholders the project will search for an optimal combination of physical, digital infrastructure and OEM equipment, easy to implement and low in costs for all parties.
In addition to the demonstrations, the project provides detailed business models for the logistics sector, demonstrating that the use of CCAM can lead to greater profits, especially when vehicles drive on a coordinated way.
The consortium consists of 8 industry partners: OEMs, ITS solutions providers, test centers and logistical companies; engineering and research providers with 4 RTOs, 3 universities; and associations of logistical companies, Tier 1 companies, ITS service providers. Complemented with road authorities and cities/regions along the corridor, representing the complete value chain. A strong stakeholder group is committed (signed LoS).
project.title: A leap towards SAE L4 automated driving features
project.keywords: CCAM, SAE level 4, logistics, trucks, automated, coordination

article.title: Paving the way for self-driving trucks
article.teaser: The MODI project is demonstrating solutions for automated freight transport to improve European supply chain logistics.

article.title: Paving the way to trustworthy and reliable automated vehicles
Heightening the perception of autonomous road vehicles

result.title: Optimal designs of physical and digital infrastructures at public roads
result.description: Optimal designs of physical and digital infrastructures at public roads considering different road levels and situations on the corridor and applicable on other corridors throughout Europe. This report includes critical elements on the motorway corridor Rotterdam – Oslo and an overview of required investments on the motorway corridor Rotterdam – Oslo for automated driving

result.title: User and stakeholder requirements
result.description: User and stakeholder requirements regarding key barriers and drivers for using automated transport for logistics – input for use cases. This deliverable is sensitive, because it contains confidential data from OEMs and other stakeholders. A publishable summary will be posted. he deliverable is related to Task 1.1

result.title: Updated Communication and Dissemination strategy
result.description: Updated Communication and Dissemination strategy. This deliverable is an update of D6.2 and related to Task 6.2

result.title: Communication and Dissemination strategy
result.description: Communication and Dissemination strategy and detailed plan, identifying WHO (target audiences), WHAT (key messages), HOW (communication channels, activities and tools) and WHEN (implementation and schedule). The deliverable is related to Task 6.2

result.title: Report on specifying the common evaluation framework for MODI-demonstrators
result.description: Report on specifying the common evaluation framework for MODI-demonstrators

result.title: Advancing Automated Freight Transport: Unveiling the Requirements and Readiness of Physical and Digital Road Infrastructure.
Border Crossing Connectivity for CCAM vehicles: A Field Test at the Norwegian-Swedish Border

details.authors: Ola Martin Lykkja (QFREE) and Petter Arnesen (SIN)

result.title: Report describing stakeholder group setup and engagement plan
result.description: Report describing stakeholder group setup and engagement plan, including the stakeholders´ commitment and relating activities. The deliverable is related to Task 6.1.

result.title: Project handbook
result.description: Project handbook describing the procedures and tools for use internally in the Consortium to facilitate communication and ensure the quality of deliverables. The deliverable is related to Task 7.2.

result.title: Report on border processes
result.description: Report in which the design is described for multiple processes at the border: pre-selection of vehicles for control, exit and stop of CCAM vehicles for control and automatic screening of cargo

result.title: Technical architecture for collaborative CCAM Fleet management and traffic management
result.description: Organisational and technical collaboration architectures for collaborative CCAM fleet management and traffic management

result.title: Periodic Reporting for period 1 - MODI (A leap towards SAE L4 automated driving features)
result.teaser: The MODI project aims to accelerate the adoption of highly automated freight vehicles to improve the efficiency of European logistic chains. The introduction of CCAM solutions is expected to significantly impact the logistics sector by reducing costs, optimising operations...

category.title: Report Summary
category.description: Result: Publishable summary (FP7 SESAM) and Summary for publication (H2020 SyGMa)

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
